F*ck it! That's it! I'm staying at Administration room and I never coming out ever again!!!!!

Imagine being locked in a bunker full of fr*nch people.

Truly very scary situation that you can think of, from the perspective of every life being, including monster.

[h1]Alien Isolation's younger brother[/h1]

Frictional games decided to tone down their usual approach to storytelling and decided to focus primarily on gameplay. Adopting elements from Resident Evil series, primarily from ones that are faithful to their survival horror tropes. Meaning inventory management, lack of resources, hostile environment, emphasis on exploration, puzzle solving and returning to places you've already been with new equipment.

You are a [b]French soldier[/b] during WW1 [strike]here should be a meme about disliking french people[/strike] stuck in a bunker with an unknown creature that I decided to name [b]Le Scary Baguette[/b], tête à tête. Game takes no time unlocking the entire layout of said bunker for you to explore, meaning that you discover everything at your own pace in whatever order you like. And what's even cooler, all items, codes for lockers, notes and traps are randomized each playthrough. 

Firearms are used mostly as a utility tool rather than a thing you constantly fight monster with. In a pinch it will save you, but don't get too cocky since ammunition is VERY SCARCE.

Bunker decided to combine all elements from titles of previous games literally:

[b]· Rebirth[/b] because the only way of saving in the game is touching a lamp in your safe house, meaning that if you die, you'd have to replay certain sections of the game all over again, and on hardest difficulty you will be dying, a lot. 
[b]· Machine[/b] because the key feature of the game is generator running on finite fuel. A lot of people seem to not understand what generator does and assume that turning it on will make monster remain docile, allowing free exploration. What it does is keeping him inside his hidey-holes longer and make him retreat earlier if provoked. The only place you are safe is in your safe house.
[b]· Descent[/b] because you will be witnessing the utter paranoia and panic of previous inhabitants of this bunker via notes that are scattered everywhere. Down here it's hell, but you are constantly reminded that if you escape it, surface will greet you with yet another hell. 

[u]Maybe staying here is a better option?[/u]

Game is not perfect. It has some performance issues, loading screens between major areas, sometimes monster clips through your hiding spot and kills you because you technically entered his hitbox along sometimes having perfect vision in pitch blackness, but not seeing you under a table in a well lit room. However I didn't feel so tense since previously mentioned [b]Alien Isolaiton[/b]. 

Game is a 9/10 for me. For an average survival horror enjoyer it delivered a very well crafted experience in a rarely seen setting. I hope this title will sell well and Frictional Games will continue making gems.

Pros

- Fantastic sound design
- You can defend yourself
- Creature ai is very smart
- Puzzles are fun
- You play as French

Cons

- You play as French.

1/10.

PS: Some people complain the game is running at 60 fps.
There's an option in the menu to run the game at 15 fps or lower, you're welcome.

Best Amnesia since the first one, actually better game design in many aspects. Must buy. 
Not the narrative heights of Soma, or the original Amnesia: The Dark Descent but mechanically this is the most interesting and dynamic horror puzzle they have created. Feels a lot like old-school Resident Evil meets Penumbra, but with a lot of lessons learned from both.
I've never been so afraid of a stopwatch hitting zero before.

Amnesia: The Bunker is not a very good Amnesia game. There is little grounding it in the lore of Amnesia. The WW1 bunker setting makes it feel a lot more like Penumbra than Amnesia. There aren't really puzzles. You get not one, but *two* guns, along with a litany of thrown weapons. That last point on its own feels a bit like sacrilege against the ethos of the subgenre that The Dark Descent was the progenitor of. Even if the weapon doesn't really do anything more than slow down the monster, having a way to defend yourself, even in such a meager way, really compromises a major facet of the game's atmosphere. The psychological impact of being truly defenseless is not felt when you're traipsing around the titular bunker armed to the teeth with more bullets and grenades than you can shake a stick at.

So if you're here looking for the next good Amnesia game after the last two fumbled the original's good name into a pair of mediocre sequels, this is not it. It's a bad Amnesia game. But as a survival horror game -- it's pretty solid!

The bunker itself is a really spooky environment. It's claustrophobic and poorly lit, even at the best of times. Your only light source in darkened areas is your hand-powered flashlight, which is loud as fuck and will attract the attention of the monster, Jerome, whenever you crank it, and the charge lasts about 15 seconds. It's a terrible flashlight, by design. Its explicitly AIDSerific nature is meant to compliment the game's core mechanic, that being the generator that you have to keep fueled up in order to keep Jerome at bay and explore the bunker unmolested, but the fuel does not last terribly long. It simultaneously offers you respite from the darkness and the promise of (relative) safety from ol' Jerry, while also pushing you into exploring the unlit and unvisited areas of the bunker to find more resources. Everything you do puts you on a timer, and you feel the pressure of the clock ticking down on you constantly. Ending up stranded in the dark in one of the farther areas of the bunker is an almost guaranteed death sentence, or at the very least a guaranteed hectic run and gun back to the stash room to get the generator up and running again. It's a great source of tension.

That core gameplay loop is actually compelling enough to carry the rest of the game almost on its own. It creates an atmosphere that is constant and oppressive, which goes hand in hand with the Frictional team's excellent map design and attention to detail. The bunker feels very lived in -- not just by its former human occupants, but also by our good friend Jerome. Let's talk about Jerome.

The monster in Amnesia: The Bunker is both its greatest strength and its greatest flaw. The dynamic AI means that Jerome is a constant looming threat no matter where you are. You'll hear him skittering around inside the walls, growling and screeching, following you everywhere. Fire a gun or toss a grenade or run around too much in an unsafe area and it's a matter of moments before Jerome's on top of you and snacking on your innards. He's very similar to the Xenomorph from Alien: Isolation, though not nearly as consistent (or consistently irritating). There are holes in the walls all throughout the bunker which Jerome uses to stalk you around the base, which are themselves a serious source of tension, especially when placed directly next to your objectives. You can usually tell when he's nearby based on all the noise he makes, but every once in a while he decides to develop a mind of his own and go off script on you. He's supposed to hate the light and stay away from it, but he'll regularly come sniffing around where he's not welcome, spawning sometimes at complete random in fully lit areas. And Jerome is FAST AS FUKK BOIIIII

Nothing will stop him. Not doors, not tables, not closets, nothing. If you hear the "peekaboo I see you " noise, you've got about 1.5 seconds to pump a few bullets in him before he mulches your ass with his 1 hit kills, very much like the Xenomorph from Isolation. If he catches you, that's it.

But here's the thing: Jerome cheats, and he's very dumb. He's supposed to have this mechanic where he can track you based on the blood trail you leave behind from being injured, but it doesn't seem to work 100% correctly. I've had instances where Jerome has smashed tables I'm under and closets I'm inside of despite having not seen me and having full health, and I've also had instances where I was nearly dead and bleeding out gallons per second while Jerome meandered past completely oblivious, lost in thought trying to decide what he's going to watch on Netflix tonight. He's also a big b with a tiny p most of the time and won't actually come out of his hideyholes in areas you've explored no matter how much sprinting, grenade tossing, or flashlight pumping you engage in, except on the odd occasions that he changes his mind about it and comes to say hello six feet away from your home base without any provocation whatsoever. I didn't really find myself constantly paranoid about Jerome like I was with the Xenomorph, because his rules are inconsistent, and he'll let you do whatever you'd like most of the time. It really saps a lot of the atmosphere by the end when it becomes a game of remembering where you have to go while some weirdo breathes heavily in the walls and occasionally screams at you rather than having to actually be mindful of the helldemon on your tail. This is itself curtailed somewhat by the game's short running time -- I beat it in just under 5.5 hours according to the in game timer, at least an hour of which was spent dying to a frustrating killbox in the penultimate area, and then dying over and over again attempting to figure out how to get out of the final arena. If one knew what they were doing and knew where things were, I could easily imagine this game being beaten in under 1.5-2 hours, probably less than that, due to how the game's mechanics are put together to only soft-gate your progress instead of hard-gating it. The game suggests some sort of replay value with randomized item placements and door/locker codes, as well as a big old stats screen at the end, but I don't really know how much mileage there is to get out of that, other than the time trial aspect of it.

The story is nothing to write home about. None of the characters are really interesting, and the protagonist's involvement with the narrative's events are mostly incidental. Henri is not Daniel or Oswald, who were the prime movers of their narratives, tortured and conflicted characters whose actions set into motion all of the events of TDD and AMFP. He's not even like Tasi from Rebirth, who might have held a different role narratively to Daniel and Oswald, but at least had some greater motivation than "survive, idiot" and a connection to the other characters in the story. Henri is... I mean, he's just kinda there. You don't really learn much of anything about him, his amnesia is incidental, and he's not really the focus of the supernatural goings-on at the heart of the story. Nobody has any thoughts about Henri, and in turn Henri has little to say about any of them. His motivation is to escape the bunker. That's it.

Maybe that's all you need to make a good video game, but I really expect a little more from an Amnesia game. There aren't even multiple endings, a staple of the series, that's how barebones the story is. It's not great.

But overall, Amnesia: The Bunker is a tight, compelling experience, one which will keep you on the edge of your seat for most of its running time. $25 might be a bit high of a price to pay for something so short, but I still definitely recommend this game. Buy on sale when you feel like being spooked for a few hours.

Here's an actual review and not Just a post-launch insta-like.
Amnesia: The Bunker is an innovative new take on the Amnesia franchise, and I think it's still recognizably an Amnesia game, despite the addition of things like firearms and grenades. Both are actually used as puzzle solving tools 90% of the time, with the other 10% being used for rat extermination (I hate those things). 
The Bunker doesn't feel like a true prequel or sequel to the other Amnesia games, instead it's more of an offshoot story, with no mention of the previous game's events. However, I found The Bunker's premise to be very interesting: The idea of discoveries from the past games bleeding their way into the lives of oblivious WW1 soldiers makes me very excited for future Amnesia games.

PROS:
-GOD I love the World War 1 setting, it's such an interesting place to be. The threat of Germans invading seems absent despite the distant gunfire, as a greater horror lurks with you in the bunker.
-Guns as puzzle solving tools is a great idea. Their noise attracts enemies, so you need to plan accordingly.
-The backstory of the bunker is extremely well written, and you're provided harrowing accounts of the nightmare through notes left around the bunker. You also find photographs that demonstrate ways to use your gear, as well as depictions of horrendous deaths
-The game doesn't always have fixed ways of solving problems, and I believe this led to me getting stuck less.
-None of the puzzles had me stuck for long periods of time, nor was there tons of long backtracking through maze-like levels
-The monster is well done and my blood ran cold with some of its encounters.
-NO CHEAP JUMPSCARES, it's psychological the whole way through.
-I only died three or so times (Though I played on easy because I think dying constantly ruins the horror)
-The Generator mechanic was quite fun. Throughout the game you find fuel and you need to bring it back to a central generator to keep the lights on. On easy mode this wasn't a drag at all, and actually made for some very scary moments when the power suddenly died. You can always see how much time the generator has left through a stopwatch in your inventory.
-The game looks great, and RAN GREAT on my GTX 1070ti

CONS:
-The game is SHORT! I beat it in 5 hours, and I think I could've beaten it in 3, maybe even 2.
-There are only two monsters: The big guy and rats.
-My experience wasn't exactly bug-free, with monsters poking their faces through walls, and wooden bits making infinite rattling noises as they lay on the ground.
-There IS a shotgun in the game, but you get it towards the end, and I only used it to open a single door.
-The ending left MUCH to be desired, and I was a little sad it ended so quick.
-Your character doesn't say a word. You only hear his voice from a few notes in the game. This is sad, because there are DEFINITELY some situations that felt incomplete without input from the character.

In conclusion, I certainly don't regret buying The Bunker, but I do wish there was more of it. I wish it had the story-telling depth and dramatic moments of Rebirth, but The Bunker still leaves me excited for the next episode of the Amnesia Story. If you're not a die-hard Amnesia fan, this is probably a game you should buy on sale. Aside from the lacking story, I thought the gameplay was fun, and the game had some novel moments. I hope The Bunker isn't just forgotten about, because I think a LOT could be done with the premise of this story, and I'm saddened again that it was so short.

Frictional, I believe The Bunker's innovations have been a success. Maybe the next game could feature ALL of France being obliterated by monsters? J-just France though... Because I think it would fit the story... Not for any other reason... just... yeah...

You play as a French man and any time the enemy appears, you run & hide.
I'd say it's an accurate depiction of the French
Great so far, hopefully Frictional will continue this style in a future game outside of the Amnesia series.

It's very short, completed it in 3 and a half hours game time. The monster in the promotional material looks significantly better than what we actually got, and they're almost doing a hello neighbour thing with how they talk about the AI of the monster, it's not intelligent or dynamic, you make a lot of noise and it appears, simple as. 

I thought that it would be a problem only getting one bullet per box of ammo, but you only need shoot the monster twice with the revolver to scare it away, and the game is short enough that it is really a non issue. I found shotgun ammo too so I was waiting to receive. You don't get it till basically the end of the game anyway so it doesn't really matter. It seems its sole purpose is for the final part of the game, which to kill the monster only actually took a single revolver round. 

Story is kinda weird, like the amnesia is very tact on. It's not a key point of the story really it's just there to give you a sense of wow we gotta find out what's going on. In the dark descent you drink a potion to cause amnesia so you can overcome the guilt you hold from the events that took place before the game, in this you drag a guy out of a ditch and an explosion going off near you gives you amnesia. But it doesn't matter anyway because your character has no life, there's nothing to him he's basically just any soldier. They also just happen to build this bunker above an ancient roman site. Shits wack.

The gameplay is standard frictional gameplay, less puzzles, they've always been good with atmosphere as well. It's just not that good to me really, it really boils down to just getting 2 items, the dynamite and the activator, and to get those you need the bolt cutters and the wrench, and to get those you go on an easter egg hunt for two keys and some dog tags. That's where the randomness and no play through is the same thing comes in, it's I guess randomised where things will spawn every new game. I'd have to replay and see because I feel like it's just the locations of these specific items and not like rooms or anything. It's just not interesting enough to keep me personally replaying. I appreciate the rats tho.

Maybe I went in with too high expectations, it's not a bad game by any means it's just kinda painfully average. I wouldn't put it above the dark descent or even penumbra overture or black plague, and I'd recommend playing those games instead. Maybe I'm just a becoming a boomer.

Can we please return to SOMA, or another game with as compelling of a story… please…

This really pains me to leave a no on this game- I’m a die hard Frictional Games fan: I was intrigued by Penumbra, Dark Descent got me hooked, and SOMA turned me into faithful follower. Call it another case of “I wish Steam didn’t just have a like/dislike rating system.” In summary I’d give this game a 6/10, but it really falls flat compared to Frictional’s other experiences. More below:

Let’s start on the bright side with some positives: I really appreciate the devs truly mixing up the gameplay and not following the same pattern they have since Penumbra. It was refreshing to play a more traditional survival horror and you could tell the devs went outside their comfort zone- so I give them credit for that. However this also comes with setbacks (more to come on that). 

Setting wise, taking place during the height of WWI deep in the trenches (with some moments surface level) was a great choice. We don’t see enough WWI games, let alone a horror survival taking place amidst one, and it’s the perfect setting for such a game that revolves around cat and mouse. 

Now onto the reasons I’m giving this a not recommend - maybe I should rephrase that to “wait for a sale instead” because what you’re getting for $30 doesn’t seem worth it. The biggest reason for me is that this game didn’t stick with me like Frictional’s past experiences have. Story wise, it fell completely flat and honestly it seemed like the story took a back seat in favour of their emphasis on survival horror. A lot of this probably has to do with their last Amnesia entry (Rebirth) and how polarizing that game was- apparently the biggest criticism with it was that it was “too much of a walking sim.” Fair, but at the end of the day, that game’s story and characters- and not to mention it’s ending - really stuck with me compared to Bunker. Bunker had one of the most lack lustre, anticlimactic endings I’ve experienced and I was honestly shocked how/when it ended. Truly a “that’s it?!” moment…

In terms of characters, hardly memorable at all, and there wasn’t enough to empathize or even humanize them. The VA’s really didn’t sell these characters either and of the two characters who do actually speak, I found myself muting their dialogue and simply reading their diary entries on my own because their voices were more distracting than immersive. To me, they simply weren’t selling their emotions, or the horror of the situation they were in. The quasi French accents weren’t doing it either. They should have just hired French VA’s and used subtitles. Also, like I just said: only two voiced characters- really shocking when you look back at Rebirth and SOMA. Those two games were filled with a diverse cast of memorable characters. No idea why more of the notes/entries couldn’t have been voiced here to help sell the terror these soldiers faced in the bunker. 

Now I mentioned the change to true survival horror being a plus, but it hinders the game at the same time. The entire game, or rather map is given to you all at once, and in turn you’ll be back tracking a lot to “unlock” areas. In the beginning it’s fun and tense tiptoeing out of the admin room to a new area, then running back and slamming the door behind you, but after a few times, you realize you’ve been essentially everywhere and it all looks the same. I get it, it’s a dark claustrophobic bunker, but looking back at SOMA, think about all the truly unique different environments you got to explore at the bottom of the ocean, from sprawling science facilities, to power plants, ship wrecks and the abyssal plains of the depths. Even Rebirth for that matter with its desert, oasis, forts, catacombs, “alien worlds,” etc. None of that exists in Bunker, and like its namesake, you get a bunker (save for a brief moment at the end, no spoilers). It sort of felt like a more fleshed out “Monstrum” (remember that game?), with respect to running around its singular environment collecting items, maybe just with a tad more story and objectives, but it plays almost identically. 

The other big thing that stands out here: this engine is getting old and tired, and it’s REALLY starting to show its age. Besides maybe a few lighting and shadow improvements, this game looks almost identical to Dark Descent. The enemy animations are still just as robotic (my god the rats…), and watching the beast jitter around and slide 90° to turn really takes you out of the immersion when you’re supposed to be terrified. It’s not not just graphically speaking either, though the engine does a fairly descent job of establishing an appropriate atmosphere given its age (at the same time the game is 90% dark, so…), but its age also shows in how clunky it feels/plays. This is ESPECIALLY apparent since they’ve gone full survival horror. I get that they want a slow experience, but you really feel like you’re controlling a 1920s diver and the combat leaves a lot to be desired (especially apparent at the end).

I also don’t understand this “Amnesia extended universe” they’ve set up. The first game stood out fine on its own and these next two entries haven’t really done it any favours? We have 3 entires in the series now (I don’t include Machine for Pigs), and I don’t really see the connection between them? That’s especially notable in this game, besides a few set pieces, I didn’t notice any parallels and I wonder if Amnesia was slapped on the title as more of a way to market it (remember 2010…) SOMA was a thought provoking, heavy hitting story with such a unique premise and environment- there’s so much more there to explore, whether it takes place on the Arc, or back on the ocean floor. Why not return there instead of continuing down this path…

Like I said, this really pains me to say, I love Frictional and honestly I’ll continue buying their games day one because I enjoy supporting them. I just really hope this isn’t their new direction because this looked and played like 90% of the asset flip, run from the spooky, you see on Steam for $10. Again, buy it on sale, my first playthrough took just under 5.5 hours, which is pretty underwhelming. Replayability is limited (sure codes and item locations change), but that’s not enough to bring me back. Going back to SOMA; that game is as LINEAR as it gets, yet I’ve played it numerous times and even watched friends play through it, all because of the compelling story and characters. That doesn’t exist here…

Frictional, if you read this, stick to what you do best: writing said compelling stories filled with gripping characters, which has the player ask questions, challenge their feelings/perceptions, and above all else, leaves them with a lasting experience THAT STICKS. Cheap thrills wear off once your heart stops beating fast. That’s what made you guys unique and stand out from the dribble that’s released by the masses.

- Sincerely a lover of Frictional

Roughly 5 days before this release my friends were trying to peer pressure me into buying an overpriced game on Blizzard that we will not name. I chose to resist and held out for this game instead. All I can say is, I made the right decision, I would have paid $110 for this experience. Absolutely terrifying, had my body pumping with adrenaline. This is a game worth my hard earned money.

10/10 would miss Diablo 4 again

I played through it on hard mode. The one playthrough took about 3.5 - 4 hours of playtime. 

This game is *fine* as far as a horror experience goes. The primary gameplay consists of a lot of resource management and problem solving while avoiding an ever-present monster chasing you. Chases are triggered by certain events, such as loud noises, walking too close to certain holes while they are active, etc

Most puzzles require a specific solution, though some can be solved through alternate means. For example, a door may be locked from the inside, requiring you to walk all the way around, but you may also use one of your very limited grenades to destroy the wood. It's an interesting idea, but contributes to this game's fatal flaw.

If you asked me what the primary focus of Amnesia as a series was, I'd simply show you the opening messages of the games that talk about how they are not games to win. They are about immersion, both in terms of mood and within the story. The first three games accomplish this goal to varying degrees. This game experiments with that formula and in doing so runs into the same issues many other non-amnesia games encounter.

The nature of The Bunker's mechanics actively works to break the player's immersion in the world. The monster's movement is almost *too* understandable to a point. The reliance on consumable items for many actions actively punishes exploration that is not focused on your objectives, punishing you for wanting to learn more about the world. It seems the developer's actively recognized the near necessity of save-scumming, as "Reload from last save" is one of the top options in the menu. That is never a good sign in a game

This game **did not** need to be an Amnesia game or at least one considered a part of the series proper. Story wise there is near 0 reason why your character has to have amnesia, especially since your character and their comrades are given next to no personality so you have little reason to care about them as a player.

If you were hoping for more lore about the eldritch world we knew of from previous games about Vitae, The Orbs, The Shadow, etc, you will be getting none of that.



I cannot recommend this game to anyone at full price. The other amnesia games were extremely short as well, but they had gripping stories that painted a picture of cosmic horrors and philosophical dread. The previous games left me thinking about their characters and the struggles they faced. The Bunker is about 4 hours of gameplay with a shell of a story that I honestly cannot remember much of. Buy it on sale or take some time to play it at a friend's house, but as it stands this game just disappoints.


Sidenote: If this game didn't want to be compared to the others in the series, it shouldn't have called itself "Amnesia" because again, the actual Amnesia plot in this entry was *barely* relevant

I've finished my first run at 3.5 hours (Normal Diff) but now i might try hard diff next
Let me just write my review here!

applist.name: Red Dead Redemption 2
applist.detailed_description:
Ultimate Edition


The Red Dead Redemption 2: Ultimate Edition delivers all of the Story Mode content from the Special Edition plus additional content for online including Bonus Outfits for your online Character, Rank Bonuses, Black Chestnut Thoroughbred and free access to the Survivor Camp Theme.

Plus get free access to Additional Weapons in online.


About the Game

America, 1899.

Arthur Morgan and the Van der Linde gang are outlaws on the run. With federal agents and the best bounty hunters in the nation massing on their heels, the gang must rob, steal and fight their way across the rugged heartland of America in order to survive. As deepening internal divisions threaten to tear the gang apart, Arthur must make a choice between his own ideals and loyalty to the gang who raised him.

Now featuring additional Story Mode content and a fully-featured Photo Mode, Red Dead Redemption 2 also includes free access to the shared living world of Red Dead Online, where players take on an array of roles to carve their own unique path on the frontier as they track wanted criminals as a Bounty Hunter, create a business as a Trader, unearth exotic treasures as a Collector or run an underground distillery as a Moonshiner and much more.

With all new graphical and technical enhancements for deeper immersion, Red Dead Redemption 2 for PC takes full advantage of the power of the PC to bring every corner of this massive, rich and detailed world to life including increased draw distances; higher quality global illumination and ambient occlusion for improved day and night lighting; improved reflections and deeper, higher resolution shadows at all distances; tessellated tree textures and improved grass and fur textures for added realism in every plant and animal.

Red Dead Redemption 2 for PC also offers HDR support, the ability to run high-end display setups with 4K resolution and beyond, multi-monitor configurations, widescreen configurations, faster frame rates and more.

Also includes access to the shared living world of Red Dead Online.

[h1][b]Vengeance Is An Idiot’s Game.[/b][/h1]
[b]Red Dead Redemption 2 is a true work of art.[/b] [list]
[*]This game takes you on a journey that is unlike any other, filled with amazing characters, an immersive open world, and an engrossing story that will keep you hooked until the very end.
The storyline is emotionally gripping and skillfully crafted, the themes of redemption and loyalty are deeply moving, and the writing is some of the best in any video game.
[*]Many different activities, dialogues and a friendly atmosphere made me spend all my time in the camp. And I like it! Every member of the Van der Linde gang feels like a real person with their own distinct personality and backstory. You'll grow to love them, hate them, and feel for them as the story progresses.[/list] [quote=Arthur Morgan][b]Vengeance Is An Idiot’s Game[/b][/quote] [list] [*]and the game drives home this point in a powerful way. The consequences of revenge are explored through the characters' actions and the outcomes that follow. The game shows that revenge only leads to more pain and suffering, and the only way to break the cycle is through forgiveness and redemption.
[*][b][u]RDR 2 is a game that you don't just play, but you live.[/u][/b] This is the best game of this generation. If you're a fan of open-world games, westerns, or just great storytelling, you owe it to yourself to play this game. It's an unforgettable experience that will stick with you long after the credits roll.[/list][hr][/hr]

Having previously played RDR I had a strong feeling I would enjoy the prequel just as much. I originally played RDR2 on Xbox when it launched in 2018. I fell in love with this game and it's characters straight away and spent hundreds of hours exploring everything its open world had to offer. This game is an absolute masterpiece and one of the best games I have ever played. The attention to detail in this game is incredible. I could spend hours wandering around the wilderness admiring it's atmosphere. The campaign is one of the best adventures I have ever experienced. The only bad thing about the story is the emptiness you feel as soon as it ends.

[b] Introduction [/b]
This is one of the games where I would just turn cinematic camera on and enjoy the immersion. [b][i] Do note that I don't usually write a review or make an essay out of it but this game deserve one!. [/i][/b] The game itself is very immersive probably one of the best I've experienced. The landscapes are awe-inspiring, from the rugged mountains to the rolling plains, each with its own distinct atmosphere and beauty. The attention to detail is staggering, with dynamic weather and realistic animal behavior breathing life into the surroundings. It's a world that basically begs players to explore.

[b] Development [/b]
The greatest thing R2D2 have to offer is the deeply engrossing character development of Arthur Morgan. As a member of the Van der Linde gang, Arthur is a complex protagonist with a troubled past and a conflicted moral compass. Through the course of the game, players witness his transformation from a loyal outlaw blindly following his leader to a man questioning his actions and searching for redemption. The writing and voice acting are exceptional, capturing the nuances of Arthur's personality and emotional growth.

[b] World Immersion[/b]
The open world is filled with diverse missions, side quests, and activities that complement the overarching story. Whether engaging in intense shootouts (as always~), doing heists, or simply exploring the wilderness, the gameplay remains consistently captivating. I have over 70+ hours now and I haven't even complete my first playthrough (due to exploring the map, side-activities and irl education/work). With all that, there are still things which I have yet too discover! Like who is Gavin??!

[b] TRY IT! [/b]
Whether you're drawn to the allure of the Wild West or simply appreciate a masterfully story driven game, Red Dead Redemption 2 is an absolute must-play. While writing this down I should also note that Arthur Morgan is hands down the best protagonist out there!<3

[h3]Now THIS is how to tell a story.[/h3]
Red Dead Redemption 2 features the most gripping narrative I’ve ever seen in a video game. The epic journey of Dutch Van der Linde's gang of outlaws is full of so many jaw-dropping, cinematic, action-packed moments, but still stays believable as the protagonist Arthur Morgan slowly frees himself of his life-long gunslinger ideals. And every character in the Van der Linde gang’s saga feels remarkably human, thanks to fantastic writing and voice acting that perfectly complement this game’s stunning visuals, detailed animation and beautiful music.

All of these elements combine to make the world of Red Dead 2 come alive in a way that no other open world game does. The massive five-state map is incredibly dynamic, with missions, side quests and random events of equally high quality perfectly interwoven into an enchanting world that constantly changes with the flow of the main story. And there are so many little details throughout this game - from memorable NPCs to colorful customization options to fleshed-out minigames - that make the experience feel authentic.

Even though I absolutely loved the phenomenal story and atmospheric world of Red Dead 2, the gameplay mechanics can seem shallow when taken out of context. Granted, there’s nothing wrong with the core controls - the shootouts are fun even on controller thanks to the Deadeye time-slowdown ability, and riding around on a horse is simple but satisfying. However, responsive controls are sometimes de-emphasized in favor of handholding gameplay and "realism" in regard to difficulty and mission structure. Horses automatically steer themselves on rough terrain, animations make looting and crafting take longer, many missions include trailing sections so the player can get where they need to go… et cetera.

Usually, when a game prioritizes realism over immediate gameplay like this, there’s a weak link somewhere that breaks my immersion - such as bad voice acting, weak writing, faults in sound design or visuals, or spacing of content around the map. And this usually results in these “realistic” game mechanics becoming more tedious than they are immersive, distancing me from whatever atmosphere is trying to be established. But.. this isn’t the case with Red Dead Redemption 2.

[h3]Red Dead 2 might be the first game to [i]fully convince[/i] me of its own world's authenticity.[/h3]
The immaculately detailed world and unbelievably human characters of RDR2 breathe life into in-game tasks that I would normally consider boring, like trailing missions, herding animals and catching fish - making even these less inspired gameplay segments pretty damn fun. The gameplay mechanics aren’t untouchable on their own, but the sixty-hour-long story pretty much is, and it’s paired with an intricate portrayal of 1899 America that makes the narrative just as enthralling as some of the greatest movies and TV shows ever made. This commitment to realism and thorough storytelling makes even the slower paced segments of the game exciting, and the intense parts (like shootouts) more meaningful.

I’m already partway through my second playthrough now, and I’m having even more fun this time around trying to dissect the incredible character dynamics and details of the open world now that I’ve beaten the game already. The more I play Red Dead 2, the more fascinated I am with the spectacular story and cast of characters - and the few issues I originally had with the mechanics have become less and less noticeable in the grand scheme of RDR2’s monumental scope. Rockstar has created a true masterpiece here, and the gripping tale of outlaw Arthur Morgan is a story I’ll never forget. 10/10

RDR2 undoubtedly stands as a masterpiece in the realm of open-world games, solidifying its place as a true GOAT contender. With its vast and immersive world, the game offers an unparalleled level of freedom and a staggering number of quests that cater to a wide range of player preferences and interests.

One of the most remarkable aspects of RDR2 is its sheer scope. The game presents players with a sprawling open world, meticulously crafted and teeming with life. From the bustling cities to the untamed wilderness, every inch of the game is bursting with breathtaking detail and realism. As you traverse the landscape, you'll encounter dynamic weather patterns, diverse wildlife, and a rich ecosystem that reacts organically to your actions. This level of attention to detail creates an immersive experience that draws players into the vibrant and authentic Old West setting.

Questing in RDR2 is a true delight. The game offers an impressive variety of missions, ensuring that players can find their niche and embark on a personal journey within the game's narrative. Whether you're drawn to intense shootouts and thrilling heists or prefer more peaceful pursuits like hunting or fishing, RDR2 caters to every playstyle. The quests are expertly crafted, with engaging storylines, memorable characters, and unexpected twists that keep you hooked from beginning to end. Each quest feels purposeful and contributes to the overall narrative, making the game feel cohesive and rewarding.

Beyond the main story quests, RDR2 provides an abundance of side activities and optional objectives, guaranteeing that players will always have something to discover or pursue. From challenging bounty hunts to stumbling upon hidden treasures, the game is brimming with content that encourages exploration and rewards curiosity. Additionally, the game features a dynamic honor system that responds to your choices and actions, allowing for different gameplay experiences and multiple story outcomes.

Furthermore, the level of detail in RDR2 extends beyond the quests themselves. The world feels alive, populated by a diverse cast of characters, each with their own unique stories and motivations. Engaging in random encounters or interacting with the residents of the game world often leads to unexpected and memorable experiences. Whether it's engaging in a lively conversation in a saloon, stumbling upon a group of outlaws in the wilderness, or witnessing a dramatic event unfold before your eyes, RDR2 constantly surprises and immerses you in its living, breathing world.

In conclusion, Red Dead Redemption 2 is an unparalleled free-world game that deserves its status as a GOAT. With its vast and immersive world, diverse range of quests, and meticulous attention to detail, the game sets a new standard for open-world experiences. RDR2 invites players to embark on a personal journey within its captivating narrative, ensuring that every player can find their own niche and create their own unforgettable adventures in the Old West.

applist.name: Kingdom Come: Deliverance
applist.detailed_description:
Special Offer


About the Game

Game:

You're Henry, the son of a blacksmith. Thrust into a raging civil war, you watch helplessly as invaders storm your village and slaughter your friends and family. Narrowly escaping the brutal attack, you grab your sword to fight back. Avenge the death of your parents and help repel the invading forces!

Story:

Bohemia – located in the heart of Europe, the region is rich in culture, silver, and sprawling castles. The death of its beloved ruler, Emperor Charles IV, has plunged the kingdom into dark times: war, corruption, and discord are tearing this jewel of the Holy Roman Empire apart.

One of Charles' sons, Wenceslas, has inherited the crown. Unlike his father, Wenceslas is a naive, self-indulgent, unambitious monarch. His half-brother and King of Hungary, Sigismund the Red Fox, senses weakness in Wenceslas. Feigning good will, Sigismund travels to Bohemia and kidnaps his half-brother. With no king on the throne, Sigismund is now free to plunder Bohemia and seize its riches.

In the midst of this chaos, you're Henry, the son of a blacksmith. Your peaceful life is shattered when a mercenary raid, ordered by King Sigismund himself, burns your village to the ground. By bittersweet fortune, you are one of the few survivors of this massacre.

Without a home, family, or future you end up in the service of Lord Radzig Kobyla, who is forming a resistance against the invasion. Fate drags you into this bloody conflict and shoves you into a raging civil war, where you help fight for the future of Bohemia.

Features:

  • Massive realistic open world: Majestic castles, vast fields, all rendered in stunning high-end graphics.
  • Non-linear story: Solve quests in multiple ways, then face the consequences of your decisions.
  • Challenging combat: Distance, stealth, or melee. Choose your weapons and execute dozens of unique combos in battles that are as thrilling as they are merciless.
  • Character development: Improve your skills, earn new perks, and forge and upgrade your equipment.
  • Dynamic world: Your actions influence the reactions of the people around you. Fight, steal, seduce, threaten, persuade, or bribe. It’s all up to you.
  • Historical accuracy: Meet real historical characters and experience the genuine look and feel of medieval Bohemia.

Wonderful game. Got the royal edition on a steam sale for 12.00, and originally hated it, downloaded it, died about 30 times in the first 10 minutes of the game and deleted it considering it a wasted 12 dollars. A few months later i looked into it and found that you're supposed to be inept in the beginning and that you gradually get better as your character learns more moves. You may know what to do in a fight, but Henry is a Blacksmith's son, he doesn't. You arent special, or born to be great, you're a nobody.
 Redownloaded  and took my time to learn gameplay and practicing skills. Love it, the realism to the learning curve of combat and subtle additions like "learning to read." Great game, I highly recommend it.

Masterpiece 

and challenging combat

Riddled with bugs and glitches but can do whatever you want in the game so there are a lot of variables to consider.

A great game, despite the occasional bugs and glitches, the game is really fun. HOWEVER, BE WARNED, THE GAME DOES REQUIRE YOU TO BE PATIENT WITH IT, you get to watch yourself and the protagonist slowly develop as a character and combatant as well as you develop in mechanics.

For a small studio I really do commend their work, I'm nowhere near European decent nor christian but I went to the game with an open mind and because I like history and do know a thing or two about medieval history  and was quite satisfied with it, the world and atmosphere are amazing, side quests and DLCs can keep the game up to 120hrs+ but after you finish those there is little to do in this game and you either start a new game or just quit and forget about it until the next time you open it. 

Overall I give this game a solid 8 out of 10 and I would recommend it.

I remember playing the [i]Kingdom Come: Deliverance[/i] demo a few years ago, it was really sturdy and it barely worked. When the full version released I was very sceptical about the game, especially given that reviews were talking about many technical problems. [b]After all [i]KC:D[/i] turned out to be a masterpiece.[/b]

I have played this game 3 times, every playthrough was giving me more fun and joy. [i]Kingdome Come: Deliverence[/i] is a very well-writen RPG with rich characters and dialogue. You won't experience dull, storyless missions in it. [b]The best parts about the game are the graphics and level design. They are gorgeous![/b]

[b]If you have not tried this game before - now is the time![/b]

Kingdom Come: Deliverance is, without a doubt, *the* definitive middle-ages "life simulator". 

It is, without exaggeration, brutally difficult, unforgiving, and amazingly educational, all at the same time. 

A tremendous attention to detail has been paid, at basically every level, and one of the most entertaining aspects of the game is the "Lore" which you unlock as you progress: True and accurate historical information about the area, environment, way of life, and more. The entire game is a history lesson, disguised as a brutally difficult RPG. 

When I say brutally difficult, I absolutely mean brutally difficult: The combat system is insanely difficult to use, and will lead to a lot of frustration, however it's also well executed: the battles are crunchy, and you will definitely die - a lot. 

Kingdom Come: Deliverance has a very dense "choices matter" role-playing system, and the game will progress wildly differently depending on which path you take. 

This game is not without its flaws, however I think those can be overlooked when considering the over-all achievement. 

Two thumbs up!

The immersive experience you get from playing this game is truly profound. It's astonishing how everything, from the captivating story to the engaging side missions and the rich character dialogue, comes together so flawlessly. This game is a masterpiece.

This game is incredibly immersive and seriously fun. It's so refreshing playing a game with a challenging combat system where your personal skill grows with the stats.

You play as Henry, who's just a young blacksmith in a small town somewhere in Bohemia. Not some knight, or hero, just Henry. And Henry is not trained in combat, you learn this very early on if you try to be the hero. The game is fully open world after the intro. You are free to pursue any kind of life you'd like to live. There are many decisions you can make throughout the game regarding who you interact with and what quests you decide to pursue, which determine the person Henry becomes. 

The combat in this game is so much fun. Trust me, the first time you try it, you'll probably be annoyed because it feels clunky and non-intuitive. However, this is the point. Henry is not some combat expert, he's just some villager. You won't be able to take on experienced mercenaries or soldiers at first until you get some training (which is available pretty early in the game). One complaint I have is that combat with multiple enemies is very frustrating and selecting who you're targeting is very clunky. They could work on that, but I account it as realistic because it's disorienting and challenging to be outnumbered in this style of combat. 

The characters are all voiced and interesting. The main story is engaging and personal, and the side characters and quests they give are really fun. None of them felt shallow or like a waste of my time, even if there weren't good rewards for completing the quests they were so engaging that I enjoyed completing them. The immersion this game produces is unlike any other I've played, you really feel like some dude in 15th century Bohemia trying to figure it all out. It's so worth your time, I highly recommend this game, right now it's on sale at $7 and I'd easily say it's worth $60.

[h1]Kingdom Come: Deliverance - A Gritty and Realistic Medieval RPG[/h1]

[h2]Visuals[/h2]
Immerse yourself in the meticulously recreated medieval world of Kingdom Come: Deliverance. The game's visuals strive for realism, presenting a historically accurate depiction of 15th-century Bohemia. From sprawling landscapes to meticulously designed castles and villages, every detail is crafted with precision and authenticity. The attention to historical accuracy in the visuals transports you back in time, creating a truly immersive and visually stunning experience.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
Embark on a realistic and immersive medieval RPG experience in Kingdom Come: Deliverance. As a humble blacksmith's son, you'll navigate a world filled with political intrigue, epic battles, and personal quests for redemption. The gameplay emphasizes realism, requiring you to engage in realistic combat, manage your character's needs, and make decisions that have lasting consequences. The immersive open-world exploration, deep character development, and branching quests offer a rich and engaging gameplay experience.

[h2]Realism and Historical Accuracy[/h2]
Kingdom Come: Deliverance prides itself on its commitment to historical accuracy and realism. The game meticulously recreates the customs, culture, and hardships of medieval life, offering a unique and authentic experience. From the realistic combat system, where every swing and parry matters, to the attention to detail in the clothing, architecture, and social hierarchies, the game's commitment to realism immerses you in a world that feels alive and historically grounded.

[h2]Compelling Storyline[/h2]
The narrative of Kingdom Come: Deliverance is a compelling and intricately woven tale. As you navigate the political landscape and unravel the secrets of your character's past, you'll encounter memorable characters, engage in morally ambiguous choices, and experience the consequences of your actions. The storyline is immersive, filled with rich dialogue, and steeped in historical context. It's a story that keeps you engaged and invested, offering a sense of purpose and urgency as you progress.

[h2]Immersive Sound Design[/h2]
The sound design of Kingdom Come: Deliverance adds depth and realism to the game. The ambient sounds of nature, bustling villages, and clashing swords create a sense of immersion and authenticity. The voice acting is superb, bringing the characters to life with convincing performances. The evocative musical score sets the tone for each moment, heightening the emotional impact of the story and the intensity of the gameplay.

In summary, Kingdom Come: Deliverance offers a gritty and realistic medieval RPG experience. With its stunning visuals, immersive gameplay, commitment to historical accuracy, compelling storyline, and immersive sound design, it stands as a standout title in the genre. If you're a fan of immersive RPGs and crave a deep and authentic medieval experience, Kingdom Come: Deliverance is a game that should not be missed. Prepare to be transported to a meticulously recreated medieval world and embark on an epic journey of adventure, intrigue, and personal growth.

The combat is a pain in the fucking ass. It can become more fun, once you grind up the combat levels to the point that no longer can every peasant with a rusty shovel master strike all of your hits and endlessly slap you in the face. The combat forces you to play EXTREMELY defensively, if you attack most of your hits will be parried or countered by whats referred to as a master strike, a counter that is unblockable. Once you get to higher levels you actually have a chance of being offensive and going after hits without all attacks being blocked or countered, but that will only be much later on in the game.

Story

bugs

There are a few bugs in the game but most of them are minor, a small sidequest not giving you a small cash reward, one of the quests having a bugged speech check (you dont fail the quest but you do end up in jail for a short period, ive seen on the wiki that its claimed to be bugged so this isnt me just failing the speech check for magic reasons). But overall the game is pretty bug free so you shouldnt have any worries

at the end of the day as stated at the start, overall a pretty good game and I recommend playing it

Kingdom Come: Deliverance is easily one of the best RPGs I've ever played. The story is fascinating in depth (not least because of the historical setting) and sprawling in scope.  The extensive non-combat options and open-ended quest solutions alongside the (initially awkward) difficult melee combat encourage diverse playstyles. Make no mistake. Kingdom Come: Deliverance is definitely a slow-burner. The main story itself takes a couple of hours before fully emerging. The various skills also require a good amount of practice before you're even close to mastery. The payoff is more than worth it, with all skills being extremely satisfying to pull off once mastered. 

The locations feel alive and all the villages have their own distinctive feel. Traveling is a joy and the forests are simply breathtaking. They feel real and dense. There are picturesque places and they are not few and far between. This means that the game is not mindless traveling between activity/quest to activity/quest. Locations need to be revisited fairly frequently and the map is not terribly large. This turns out to be an advantage to the game, eschewing a focus on transport mechanics and instead developing lots of environmental interaction.

The artwork deserves a special mention for its intricate and informative inclusion. In the in-game murals, the loading screens, character screens, and the like, the artwork is detailed and immerses the player in the time and place. The Codex is a lovely addition, giving basic historical information on the main locations, characters, events, etc. The sound design is splendid with brilliant and immersive voice acting and very moving and memorable pieces in the soundtrack.

The central characters are well-fleshed out and ambiguous enough to feel human (and not a caricature). The DLCs add to the existing characters quite a bit (especially recommend A Woman's Lot and The Amorous Adventures of Bold Sir Hans Capon) and the others are nice little additions (From the Ashes is a mini-city management quest). The only places where I can hope for improvement are the somewhat under-explored politics of the time (only emerging towards the end as the main character is finally politically entangled with Sigismund's invasion) and the slightly uniform nature of non-central NPCs. The Cumans are under-explored as characters (as almost no dialogue is possible, they become a caricature-like invading force of foreign mercenaries). More complex interactions with prominent non-Czech characters and non-combatant Czechs would be welcome.  Related to this is the slightly under-emphasized area of the role of non-combatant characters in the political struggle. Jan Hus' reformist ideas are on display in a key quest but the religious conflict of the time, especially premonitions of the Hussite war, feels somewhat diminished in the game.

Other technical aspects like the bugs and rendering problems have been largely fixed, with only the occasional getting stuck in the gap between rocks and needing to fiddle with the jump button before getting out.

Overall, I highly recommend Kingdom Come: Deliverance to any RPG fan, historical game fan, or even anyone wanting to play a highly immersive story. Warhorse, on the whole, has done a stellar job with this game. I am absolutely keeping my eye out for a sequel.

What this game is not:
This is not Assassin's Creed. The bad guys will not wait their turn and come at you one at a time. They will swarm you and they will EF you up.
This is not Shadow of Mordor. You are neither a trained military person, nor are you skilled at anything at the start. You cannot just run into a group of bad guys, spam the counter button, and kill everything (At least until you have leveled up significantly and have good equipment). The game will beat that fact into you with zero apologies.
This is not Skyrim. If you rush through the intro and then piss off into the world the second the game lets you then you will be wrecked by ANYONE who decides to attack you. Keep following the story quests at least until you learn blocks and parries.
This is not Just Cause. You cannot just run around causing mayhem. (Well, you CAN, but not if you want to get any of the story or really be able to do much of anything in any of the towns)

What this game is:
This is a great time if you're willing to take the time to enjoy it. The game knows that it's not everyone's cup of tea and is 100% unapologetic about that. But if you take the game as it exists it will take you on one hell of a ride.
This is as complex as you're willing to let it be. You can beat the main story in as little as 2 hours and 5 minutes (Per Speedrun.com) or if you want to do all the side quests and DLC and take your time (like me) then you can spend hundreds of hours on a single play through.

Some random advice about the game I wish I had been given before I started playing or that helped me greatly:
Seriously, stick with the main story quest line until you unlock the weapons trainer in Rattay, and then IMMEDIATELY use him and learn blocks and parries and practice so you level up a bit and get a handle on the fighting mechanics. Fighting gets SO much easier after that.
Pick ALL the flowers you have the patience for at the start. There's a couple buffs and skills you can get from picking flowers that are Godsends in the early game. I wandered around Skalitz picking all the flowers and because I did that I left the intro area with a couple level ups, a few buffs, and all the potion material I would need for quite some time.
Bows are your friends in the early game (as long as you have armor for your forearms). You cannot touch anyone other than other nobodies when it comes to fighting at the start, so grab a bow (not a longbow) and some arrows and you can fire while backing away from the adversary. It's super easy to get head-shots doing this so you kill them faster and you end up with an achievement!
I know, it's a medieval game, everyone wants to main a sword, but seriously; go with some form of a bonk-stick. (whether that's a mace, club, warhammer, etc. is up to you) Later in the game you WILL be facing people with serious armor and the bonk-sticks are great for making the bad guys take involuntary permanent naps; whereas you can nail an armored assailant several times with a sword and have little to no impact on their alive-ness.
You can get a dog really early on. I've heard it's of decent use in the early game. I wouldn't know because I wandered off into the world without following any of the quests that activated once I was out of the intro. The dog apparently can get in the way of being a sneaky-boi, so if that's your play-style maybe pass on the dog.
Speaking of dogs: take out any that are with your adversary. They will drain your ability to do jack and leave you helpless, so turn those puppers into pincushions without remorse.
Alchemy: Learn it. Love it. You can make Saviour Schnapps (potions you need to save the game when you aren't close to a bed you own) which usually cost you in the neighborhood of 100 coins. Not a terrible price, but early on you don't want to be blowing all your money on that stuff.
Speaking of blowing money: Loot everything at the start. Any bad guy you kill should be stripped of everything of value early on. As soon as you have a horse you can just transfer stuff to the horse and not have to worry about the weight. Pick a town that will be your base of operations and sell everything you can to the local traders and merchants. Even if they have no money left to give you. They will turn around and sell everything they buy from you that they don't usually carry and then their funds will be higher so you can sell them more stuff then next time around. (It does reportedly take a couple days for this process to happen, I'm never in a town frequently enough to check) By the late game if you are doing this regularly you can have merchants and traders with purses in the 5 digit range, which makes stuff like the "From the Ashes" DLC easier as you will need a decent chunk of change for that.

Anywho, I'm just rambling now, so I'm gonna shuddap.
I think the game is worth the full price, but definitely pick it up if it goes on sale again with a decent discount.

Highlights


About the Game

The World’s Game

EA SPORTS™ FIFA 23 brings The World’s Game to the pitch, with HyperMotion2 Technology that delivers even more gameplay realism, both the men’s and women’s FIFA World Cup™ coming to the game as post-launch updates, the addition of women’s club teams, cross-play features*, and more. Experience unrivaled authenticity with over 19,000 players, 700+ teams, 100 stadiums, and over 30 leagues in FIFA 23.



This game includes optional in-game purchases of virtual currency that can be used to acquire virtual in-game items, including a random selection of virtual in-game items.

FIFA 23: The Worst Game in the History of Gaming
Warning: Proceed at your own peril. FIFA 23 is a disgrace to the gaming community and a tragic waste of your time, money, and sanity.

As a long-time fan of football and video games, I never thought I'd see the day when I would be forced to write such a scathing review. But here we are, with FIFA 23, a game that has not only failed to live up to its predecessors, but has also managed to become an unmitigated disaster in every sense of the word.

I cannot emphasize enough how bad FIFA 23 is. Imagine a steaming pile of garbage on your doorstep, and you're getting close. This game is so deplorable, it's almost an insult to refer to it as a "game." It's more like a cruel prank, a travesty that shakes the very foundations of the gaming world.

Sickening Gameplay
If you thought the gameplay in previous FIFA titles was smooth and enjoyable, prepare to be bitterly disappointed. FIFA 23 has taken all the elements that made its predecessors great and thrown them out the window. The controls are clunky, unresponsive, and frustrating. It's as if the developers coded the game with their eyes closed and their hands tied behind their backs.

Disgraceful Graphics
Despite having access to next-gen technology, FIFA 23 looks like it was made in the late '90s. The graphics are so abysmal that it's difficult to tell which pixelated blob is supposed to represent your favorite footballer. The stadiums, the crowd, and even the grass on the pitch – everything is an eyesore.

Unforgivable In-Game Purchases
FIFA 23 has taken microtransactions to an entirely new level of greed. It's as if EA Sports wants to suck every last cent out of your pocket. The game is so heavily designed around in-game purchases that it's virtually impossible to progress or enjoy the experience without shelling out an exorbitant amount of money.

A Laughable Career Mode
The career mode in FIFA 23 is an absolute joke. It's as if the developers put no thought or effort into creating a compelling and immersive experience. Instead, they've given us a shallow, uninteresting, and downright boring mode that will make you question why you even bothered to turn on your console.

To Sum It Up
FIFA 23 is, without a doubt, the worst game ever created. It's an affront to the gaming community and a disgrace to the FIFA franchise. If you value your time, money, and sanity, stay far away from this abomination.

Do yourself a favor and avoid FIFA 23 at all costs. This is not a game. It's a nightmare.

STAR WARS Jedi: Survivor™ Deluxe Edition

Unlock exclusive cosmetic items inspired by Han Solo™ and Luke Skywalker™, as seen in STAR WARS: A New Hope, with Star Wars Jedi: Survivor Deluxe Edition*.

  • The “Galactic Hero” Cosmetic Pack includes:
    • “Scoundrel” Cosmetic
    • “Rugged” BD-1 Cosmetic
    • "DL-44” Blaster Set

  • The “New Hero” Cosmetic Pack includes:
    • “Rebel Hero” Cosmetic
    • “BD-Astro” BD-1 Cosmetic
    • “Rebel Hero” Lightsaber Set


About the Game

The story of Cal Kestis continues in Star Wars Jedi: Survivor™, a third-person, galaxy-spanning, action-adventure game from Respawn Entertainment, developed in collaboration with Lucasfilm Games. This narratively driven, single-player title picks up 5 years after the events of Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order™ and follows Cal’s increasingly desperate fight as the galaxy descends further into darkness. Pushed to the edges of the galaxy by the Empire, Cal will find himself surrounded by threats new and familiar. As one of the last surviving Jedi Knights, Cal is driven to make a stand during the galaxy’s darkest times — but how far is he willing to go to protect himself, his crew, and the legacy of the Jedi Order?
